caption.p: Inverse correlation between the time between viral isolations for consensus sequence determination, and the calculated rate of evolution. Animals sustain the replication (inside curved arrow) of a virus that will be transmitted to a susceptible animal. The time that the virus spends outside an animal (absence of replication) is depicted by a horizontal arrow. The time of virus isolation is given by t1, t2, and t3. The number of nucleotide differences in the virus isolates relative to the sequence of the initial reference virus (from the animal on the left) is given by d1, d2, and d3 (vertical arrows). Because of the increasing periods of stasis (addition of horizontal arrows), calculated rates of evolution given by the d/ t ratio will be higher the shorter the time interval between isolations. See text for additional models of time effects of evolutionary rates, and references.
